executive_summary: An uptick in infrastructure investment has allowed electric power transmitters to raise rates, increasing revenue and profit. Since the need for electricity is inelastic, economic shifts typically do not impact transmission companies considerably. While commercial and industrial businesses were affected during lockdowns, residential consumers used more electricity because of stay-at-home orders, cushioning the blow from the slump in other sectors. As the economy reopened, revenue swelled, stemming from a combination of higher electricity prices and an expanding customer base. Overall, industry revenue is set to expand at a CAGR of 0.8% to $501.9 billion in 2024, including a 0.1% uptick in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: VOLATILE ECONOMIC CONDITIONS RARELY MAKE A DENT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since the need for electricity is inelastic, economic uncertainty isn't overly disruptive to electric power transmission companies. While the pandemic forced nonessential businesses and industrial factories to close, the slowdown was mitigated by the residential sector remaining intact, with customers staying home, leading to higher electricity usage.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Infrastructure Advancements Continue to Come on the Horizon
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Public utility commissions allow companies to increase their electricity rates in exchange for transmission infrastructure investments. This benefits large companies with significant capital. Even so, infrastructure construction has become saturated over the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Incentives Fuel the Growth of Renewable Energy
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Electricity generated from renewable sources (solar, wind, hydroelectric) has escalated amid environmental concerns. Government incentives like tax credits have led more businesses and households to switch to renewable energy, expanding the need for electric power transmission companies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Shift Towards Renewables Will Continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Renewable energy use will continue to expand throughout the outlook period. The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) provides tax credits on various clean energy technologies, making them more affordable for consumers and businesses.

Smart grid technology is set to become more consistent over the outlook period, increasing power optimization while lowering consumption. The technology allows consumers and businesses to reduce usage during peak hours to lower their bills.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Assistance Remains Crucial for the Transmission
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Bipartisan Infrastructure Act will provide a $65.0 billion investment in power infrastructure upgrades. Over a thousand miles of new transmission lines will be built to aid the expansion of renewable energy. Many older power lines and grids will also receive upgrades through this funding, bolstering reliance and durability.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE TRANSPORTATION SECTOR GETS A BOOST
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While transportation is a small market for power transmitters, new laws and incentives are set to aid this market moving forward. President Biden's push toward electric vehicles (EVs) will require more power to be transmitted to this sector. The Biden Administration aims to have 50.0% of new car sales be electric by 2030.

industry_definition: This industry transmits and distributes electricity from power generators to distribution centers, other electric utilities and final consumers. The transmission system includes lines and transformer stations, while the distribution system consists of lines, poles, meters and wiring that deliver the electricity to final consumers. This industry does not generate electricity.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Price of electric power

key_trends: Differentiation is a key strategy for electricity companies. By offering extra services like gas and telephone, they become a convenient one-stop shop for customers' utilities.
Very few substitutes exist for electric power transmission. While a few companies generate electricity themselves, this accounts for less than 1.0% of the total electricity supply.

Investment in infrastructure and technology is driving growth in the transmission sector. Smart grids and government funding push companies to innovate and reduce costs while expanding capacity and reliability.

Renewables and decarbonization efforts are reshaping the energy landscape. Government incentives and the push for cleaner energy sources mean electric power transmission companies are adapting to manage more sustainable power supplies effectively.
Exelon aims to halve its greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve net zero by 2050. This goal will be met primarily through infrastructure modernization and clean vehicle investments.

In February 2022, Exelon completed the separation of its generation businesses, forming Constellation Energy Corporation to manage its nuclear assets. This strategic move allows Exelon to focus on modernizing the energy grid and improving customer experience.

The USDA's $266 million investment in rural areas will give them a green-energy boost. The funds will support renewable and energy-efficiency projects to help rural communities reduce energy costs and increase job opportunities.

The Bipartisan Infrastructure Law aims to modernize the power grid for better resilience. This is a push to upgrade and expand transmission lines so the power grid can withstand extreme weather and improve energy distribution across the country.
Investing in power infrastructure allows companies to raise rates charged to customers, increasing profit. This is only available to companies with a large grasp of a regional area.
The ability to retain skilled workers is critical. This leads to high wage costs in the industry as companies must deploy engineers and technicians to ensure transmission occurs without a hitch.
The Great Lakes are home to many manufacturers, making it an ideal location for power transmitters. The region has historically been a prime location for automobile manufacturers.

Metropolitan cities provide a steady market for transmission companies. These cities bolster the residential and commercial markets by driving the need for expanded transmission networks, improving reliability and facilitating the integration of renewable energy sources.

Renewable energy sources are gaining ground in the market but are considered intermittent and potentially unreliable. Solar and wind power struggle because of inefficient energy storage technology, but they have benefited from recent government incentives.
The transportation market is set to expand following President Biden's push toward electric vehicles and charging stations. Many major cities are upgrading fleets to hybrid and electric models.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households make up almost half of the industry's total revenue. Unlike other sectors, electricity is necessary and will always be needed in households.

Commercial businesses were hit hard during the pandemic, causing their electric usage to slip in 2020. Mass vaccination efforts have allowed businesses to reopen, causing a rebound in electric consumption.

Manufacturers and other industrial operators require electricity to produce goods like metals and cars. Many of these industries have heavy manufacturing processes which require a significant amount of electricity.
Transportation is the smallest market for electric power transmitters. This market is set to grow as electric vehicles continue to rise in popularity.

products_and_services.product_description: Natural gas remains the largest source of electricity.
Coal still holds a substantial amount of electricity generation.
Renewable energy has steadily increased its revenue share, surpassing coal to become the second-largest source of electricity.
Nuclear power is a significant source of electricity generation.
Petroleum-generated electricity has a very small share.

tier_1_suppliers: Coal & Natural Gas Power in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: All electricity must be transmitted through the Electric Power Transmission industry's transmission and distribution networks to end customers.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region contains the most significant number of electric transmission companies because it is close to many major markets like steel and automobile producers.

Much like the Southeast, the Great Lakes region hosts many manufacturing facilities. Being close to these markets helps reduce transportation costs, improve supply chain efficiency and enhance the ability to respond quickly to possible issues.

The Mid-Atlantic requires a lot of electric power transmission companies because of its highly populated cities. New York City and Philadelphia are two of the largest metropolitan cities containing a large portion of the US population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) coordinates the interconnected power systems across the country. All regional power grids are connected to one of its three power systems.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) regulates electricity transmission and commerce.
State-level public utility commissions (PUC) have jurisdiction over in-state electric power transmission and distribution.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, indicating high barriers to entry.
The industry requires high capital investments for transmission infrastructure, increasing barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Electricity companies differentiate by offering additional services like gas and telephone, becoming a one-stop shop for utilities.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Local and regional companies comprise most of the industry, with large regional players dominating their locations.
Large companies can invest more to expand infrastructure and charge higher rates, sustaining profitability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: A SKILLED WORKFORCE IS NECESSARY FOR SUCCESS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Companies require skilled workers to carry out tasks like providing power grid management and maintenance.
Profit is driven by retail electricity prices, which public utility commissions set to prevent monopolies and overcharging customers for a basic necessity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: RISING ELECTRICITY PRICES RAISE PURCHASE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent the largest expense for transmission companies and have crept up during the period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Highly skilled workers (think electrical engineers and electricians) are needed to manage power grids.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Public utility companies and similar regulatory agencies play a crucial role in overseeing and approving the rates charged.
Renewable energy requires electricity transmission to deliver power to owners.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advanced metering technology provides customers and providers accurate time electricity usage data.
This data helps customers consume electricity efficiently, so they do not have excessive bills at the end of the month.

FAQs.question: How does your company hedge against price-loss risk?
FAQs.answer: Operators that offer a variety of electricity generated by source will be less exposed to price movements.

FAQs.question: How does your company hedge against market risk?
FAQs.answer: Having a diversified client base, including customers from different markets, will keep companies in this industry from performing poorly.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage input-price risk?
FAQs.answer: Efficient procurement of energy is of great importance to electricity transmission companies.

FAQs.question: PRIVATE SUPPORT DOESN'T APPLY TO THE INDUSTRY
FAQs.answer: The Electric Power Transmission industry doesn't receive any private sector support.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use automation to reduce wage costs over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: High wages can be managed via the adoption of technology.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by the growth of electricity generated by renewable resources?
FAQs.answer: Growing renewable electricity generation has the ability to drive prices down.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology, such as smart meters and drones, to become more efficient and gain a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Investing in new technology is very important to the success of companies in this industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Keeping a minimum level of health and safety is of paramount importance.

FAQs.question: How have the environmental standards in your state affected your company's procurement or generation?
FAQs.answer: State energy standards have mandated the amount of energy procured from certain resources.
